Dear Ms. Halabicky:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4109 Program Statement
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written
Description program statement which specifically addresses all of the
following:
1

(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care,
safety, and supervision, methods for addressing
residents’ needs, implementation of treatment plans,
and discharge of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth was left at a hospital by facility staff.
Investigation The Complainant/Hospital Staff 1 was interviewed over the
phone on 05/11/2023. She stated that she was directly involved in
much of Youth A’s care during her time since coming to the
hospital. At the time of this interview Youth A was still admitted to
the hospital. Hospital staff 1 stated that Youth A was consistent
and forceful in stating that they did not want to return to placement
at the facility upon discharge from the hospital. From the
beginning of Youth A’s time at the hospital, Hospital Staff 1
recalled having good communication with the staff from the facility
and Foster Care worker. Hospital staff 1 recalled the incident in
question occurring midday on 05/09/2023. She stated she helped
escort Youth A out of the building because she had been
discharged that day. Prior to this Hospital staff 1 recalled
speaking with Foster Care worker and staff from the facility
separately but could not recall about the discharge and resulting
safety planning for how to work with Youth A if she did not
cooperate with leaving to return to the facility for placement.
Hospital staff 1 stated that she, Youth A and facility staff were out
on the sidewalk in front of the hospital for a few minutes engaging
with Youth A and attempting to convince her to leave with facility
staff and return for placement, but Youth A was refusing. Hospital
staff 1 recalled one of the facility staff being present as
Administrator 1. Hospital staff 1 stated that Youth A had not
escalated emotionally or physically but was just refusing to get in
the car to return to the facility for placement. During this
interaction, Hospital staff 1 recalled efforts being made to reach
Foster Care worker and supervisor for assistance. Hospital staff 1
stated that it was decided among the group of individuals working
with Youth A at that moment to take her back inside and go
upstairs to the unit where she had previously been admitted.
Hospital staff 1 recalled that, at no point during that conversation
was it discussed that Youth A was going to be readmitted. She
believed that facility staff would be coming inside with them to
keep engaging with Youth A and attempt to make more phone
calls. Hospital staff 1 stated that once they figured out that facility
staff was not going to be coming back inside, she was able to
connect with Foster Care worker, who was then able to contact
facility staff to come back to the hospital to continue working with
Youth A.
2

Administrator 1 was interviewed over the phone during an
unannounced face-to-face visit to the facility on 05/11/2023.
Administrator 1 stated that she was significantly involved in the
preceding events leading up to the incident in question on
05/09/2023 involving Youth A. Administrator 1 stated that Youth A
first went to the hospital on 4/26/2023 because of escalated
behavior that included property destruction at the facility as well as
self-harm and threats to staff concerns. Administrator 1 stated
that she and others on her staff had been in contact with Foster
Care worker as well as hospital staff, including Hospital staff 1,
since that day. On the date of 05/09/2023 Administrator 1 stated
that they were driving to the hospital where Youth A had been
admitted because they were intending to pick her up after being
discharged to bring her back to the facility for continued
placement. Administrator 1 recalled talking with Youth A for about
a half hour attempting to engage with her to result in her coming
back to the facility with them as intended, but Youth A continued
to state that they would not do that. Youth A did not escalate in
her emotions or behavior while they were speaking, she just
refused to come with them back to the facility as Administrator 1
recalled. Administrator 1 recalled hearing one of the hospital staff
(of which she could not recall specifically who) state something to
the effect of “I guess we’ll take her back inside then.”
Administrator 1 stated that she assumed this meant that Youth A
was going to be readmitted back to the floor where Youth A had
previously been residing. She also recalled handing Youth A’s
possessions back to hospital staff at that moment. After
Administrator 1 drove back to the facility, she stated she received
a phone call from the supervisor of Foster Care worker, who
informed her that the hospital had contacted him. Administrator 1
stated that she was then informed that Youth A had not been
readmitted to the hospital at that point and it was requested that
someone from the facility go back to supervise Youth A while the
situation continued to unfold. Administrator 1 stated that Staff 2
was sent back to the hospital to continue to provide supervision of
Youth A at that time. Administrator 1 then spoke more about the
conversations that had occurred prior to Youth A being brought
downstairs to the entrance of the hospital to be discharged and
come back to the facility. She stated that she had good
communication with Foster Care worker prior to that and safety
plans had been developed regarding the possibility that Youth A
were to run away or escalate physically, and that all were very
aware of the statements that Youth A had been making about not
wanting to come back to the facility despite that being the
placement decision made for her. Administrator 1 confirmed that
3

she, nor anyone with the facility, had signed anything specific
regarding the possible discharge of Youth A that day and that
Foster Care worker had correctly done that. Administrator 1 was
asked if she had heard clearly from any of the hospital staff that
Youth A was being readmitted when they left the sidewalk and
took Youth A back inside the hospital and she stated she had not
heard that at that time but assumed that meant that Youth A was
going to be readmitted to the hospital.
Youth A’s Foster Care worker and Foster Care supervisor were
interviewed over the phone on 05/12/2023. Foster Care worker
stated that he was in a court hearing all day on 05/09/2023 but he
was aware that Youth A was likely to be discharged and had
received positive communication from the facility about their
acceptance of placement back with them, despite Youth A’s
statements that she did not want to be there. Foster Care
supervisor stated that he handled much of the communication
during the incident in question on 05/09/2023. His first phone call
was one received from Hospital staff 1 at the hospital. Foster
Care supervisor stated that Hospital staff 1 described to him the
situation, that they had formally discharged Youth A and
attempted to have her be transported back to the facility with staff
from the program. Foster Care supervisor recalled that facility
staff had attempted to engage with Youth A for her to come back
to the program with them, but Youth A refused. Hospital staff 1
had told Foster Care supervisor that she had brought Youth A
back inside the hospital for a “change of scenery” and to continue
to attempt to engage with her, but that facility staff did not come
with them. Foster Care supervisor stated he then called
Administrator 1 to inform her of what he heard from the hospital,
confirm that Youth A had not technically been readmitted and
asked her to come back to the hospital. Foster Care supervisor
stated that Administrator 1 was understanding and had a staff go
right back to provide supervision to Youth A as the situation
continued to unfold. Foster Care supervisor also recalled
Administrator 1 stating that she assumed that Youth A was being
readmitted at the time but did not disagree with the next course of
action.
Documents reviewed:
• Notes dated 05/09/2023 were provided by the facility
documenting what occurred during their interactions with
Youth A and the incident in question. In these notes it is
described that there was communication by facility staff
with Foster Care worker that Youth A was being discharged
on 05/09/2023. The facility had prepared Youth A’s room
4

for her and went to pick her up from the hospital. The note
continues to describe the course of events of Youth A
refusing to come back to the facility, being taken back
inside to the hospital and facility staff departing the hospital
all similar to what was provided in interviews for this
investigation. When alerted that Youth A was back at the
hospital in a waiting room unattended by Foster Care
supervisor, facility staff went back to the hospital to provide
supervision of her.
• Safety Plan for Youth A dated 05/09/2023 provided by the
facility and signed by Youth A’s Foster Care worker. In this
safety plan options are described on how to respond to
Youth A if she were to become a threat to herself or others
and if she began to destroy property. It is also stated that if
Youth A refused to get in the vehicle of facility staff upon
discharge that public safety will ensure that she gets in the
vehicle as requested. Courses of action were also
described if Youth A were to run away from staff upon
discharge.
• Facility policies & procedures were provided. In response
to CCI Rule 400.4127 it is stated that the facility will
“maintain a staff to resident ratio that shall assure the
continual safety, protection, and direct care and supervision
of residents.” It goes on to describe a 3 staff to one youth
ratio specifically.
Analysis Through face-to-face contact at the facility, phone and video
interviews and documentation reviewed there was evidence to
show that the facility did not provide supervision of Youth A
without clearly knowing that she had been readmitted to the
hospital and that supervision was not required.
Conclusion Violation Established
5

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.

sir_summary.summary: Facility staff attempted to pick up Youth A from a hospital following discharge but left the youth at the hospital after she refused to return to the facility. Staff incorrectly assumed the youth was being readmitted to the hospital and would be under hospital supervision, when in fact she was left unattended in a waiting room, requiring staff to return. The investigation concluded the facility failed to ensure continual supervision as required. Culpability lies with the facility for making an assumption without clear confirmation and failing to follow its own safety procedures.
